metadata.case_name: Proprietor of Narmada Printing Works v. State of Madhya Pradesh

facts.text: Appellant is proprietor of Narmada Printing Works, Jabalpur, published book 'Madhyamic Bhoogol Part I for Classes IX and X' written by C. P. Saxena.

On 1st July 1967, State Government of Madhya Pradesh passed order under s.4(1) of Criminal Law Amendment Act 1961 forfeiting every copy of the said book (second item in Schedule, along with two others) on ground that books question territorial integrity and frontiers of India in manner likely prejudicial to safety and security of India, containing matter punishable under s.2.

Communication from Deputy Secretary dated 5th August 1967 objected to pages 138, 147 and 149 of the book containing wrong maps: maps of India, part of India, adjacent countries, Asia with grossly incorrect external boundaries; omission of Laccadive, Minicoy and Amindivi Islands; omission of Bhutan territory in some maps; ignoring Indo-Pakistan boundary in others.

Appellant filed writ petition on 29th August 1967 before Madhya Pradesh High Court challenging forfeiture order under s.5 of the Act, inter alia on ground that order did not state grounds of opinion as required by s.4.
In counter affidavit, State referred to communication of Director of Map Publications dated 21st March 1967 repeating objections to maps in the three books.
High Court dismissed writ petition on 13th March 1969, holding that impugned order stated grounds as that books contained matter questioning territorial integrity etc.
Supreme Court appeal by special leave.

legal_issues.text: Whether the forfeiture order under s.4(1) of Criminal Law Amendment Act 1961 disclosed the grounds of the opinion formed by the State Government, as required by the section.

petitioner_arguments.text: The grounds for the opinion of the State Government were non-existent in the order, as required by s.4 of the Act.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 4(1), Criminal Law Amendment Act 1961; Section 5

respondent_arguments.text: State Government was not bound to place details of information on basis of which its satisfaction was arrived at.

court_reasoning.text: High Court erred; order merely quoted words of s.2 without indicating facts, statements or representations in book offending s.2; no reference to any map or text.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Grounds must be base, foundation, motive, valid reason; conclusions of facts on which opinion based, distinguished from opinion itself.

court_reasoning.text: Book may offend via wrong maps omitting territory or depicting Indian territory as another's, or express text suggestions; order gave no such indication.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Repetition of section words is not grounds.

court_reasoning.text: Parallel in s.99A CrPC, Press Act cases, preventive detention under Art.22(5); grounds are facts or conclusions of facts, not recital of section.

holdings.text: Forfeiture order invalid for not disclosing grounds of opinion; appeal allowed on short ground.

precedents_cited.relevance: Order under Press Act insufficient if merely cites section words without facts.

precedents_cited.case_name: Arun Ranjan Ghose v. State of West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: Grounds of opinion are import/effect/tendency of matters in publication, illustrated by passages.

precedents_cited.case_name: Harnam Das v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Order under s.99A CrPC invalid without indicating which communities alienated or beliefs wounded.

precedents_cited.case_name: Naresh Chandra Ganguli v. State of West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: Grounds of detention are conclusions of facts to be communicated.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Bombay v. Atma Ram Sridhar Vaidya
precedents_cited.relevance: Grounds under Preventive Detention Act are conclusions of facts, not complete recital.

statutes_cited.name: Criminal Law Amendment Act 1961
statutes_cited.relevance: Empowers forfeiture if publication questions territorial integrity prejudicially; requires notification stating grounds of opinion; application to High Court to set aside.

statutes_cited.name: Press and Registration of Books Act 1867
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines newspaper or book for purposes of s.4.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure 1898
statutes_cited.relevance: Applies to applications under s.5; parallel provisions for forfeiture.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Examples of matters leading to forfeiture under analogous provisions.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Requires communication of grounds in preventive detention.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Press Act 1910
statutes_cited.relevance: Required stating grounds in forfeiture notifications.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; judgment and order of High Court set aside; forfeiture order of State Government quashed as it did not disclose grounds of opinion.
outcome.relief_granted: Writ petition allowed; forfeiture order set aside.

key_quotes.text: the order did number disclose the grounds of the opinion formed by the State Government.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Grounds of the opinion must mean the conclusion of facts on which the opinion is based. There can be number conclusion of fact which has number reference to or is number ex facie based on any fact.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: the repetition of an opinion cannot be its grounds, and yet that is all that the numberification furnishes in the shape of grounds.
key_quotes.speaker: Jenkins J. in In re. Mahomed Ali
key_quotes.significance: Illustrates insufficiency of merely citing section.
